journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Missile acceleration controller design using proportional–integral and non-linear dynamic control design method

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 335 Gwahangro, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon 305-701, Republic of Korea. email: shkim@fdcl.kaist.ac.kr or shadd@hanmail.net

abstract.p: In this article, a method to make the normal acceleration of medium angle of attack missile to track some desired trajectories is presented. The dynamics which describe a missile acceleration are known to be non-minimum phase, which makes it difficult to use a straightforward feedback linearization technique. This article aims at showing that this problem may be overcome by employing cascaded regulations in the non-linear area. First, inner loop controller by dynamical sliding mode control (SMC) method based on asymptotic output tracking is designed for angle of attack control which has a minimum phase characteristics. Also then, the problem that is addressed here is the completion of the global loop by designing an additional outer loop proportional–integral (PI) controller and angle of attack estimator. The performance and stability of proposed method are illustrated via computer simulations.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The dynamics which describe a missile acceleration are known to be non-minimum phase and consequently make it difficult to use straightforward feedback linearization technique. To overcome this difficulty, a number of methods have been proposed [1–9]. References [1] and [2] consist of modified minimum phase models, which ignore small coupling terms and non-minimum phase phenomenon considered as perturbations, and the new output redefinition method [3] has been used to tackle the non-minimum phase problem. However, these methods are approximation linearization method. Some applications to the missile acceleration control [4–9] are also reported. In references [4–6], the plant inversion based on feedback linearization is first applied to the control of angle of attack. Normal acceleration is then controlled by the classical integral or proportional–integral (PI) feedback. However, these methods have a weakness which can be unstable with respect to time delay. On the other hand, robust lateral acceleration autopilot [7] is designed for a tactical missile modelled as a second-order quasi-linear parameter varying system. In reference [7], the augmented lateral acceleration signal is used to overcome the effect of non-minimum phase. Also, the robust missile acceleration autopilot design methods using eigenstructure assignment approach are studied [8, 10].

The study described in this article can be seen as a continuation of the design result carried out by Siguerdidjane [11, 12]. In reference [11], angle of attack is assumed as the known value, which is perfect, and applied the asymptotic output tracking controlapproach for angle of attack control. In this article, we introduce the estimator of angle of attack for application of real missile system and apply the different controller design method for inner loop control. Control strategy is proposed to make the acceleration of high-angle of attack missile track some desired trajectory. This method consists in, first, linearizing the non-linear system with respect to an intermediate output (angle of attack), second, adding an outer loop in order to control real output (acceleration). This approach deals with non-minimum phase system without approximating or neglecting of system dynamics. In this article, we design an inner loop controller for angle of attack control, which has a minimum phase characteristics, using combined output tracking-dynamical sliding model control (SMC) method [13, 14]. This method describes the design of dynamical compensators synthesized from SMC technique and is based on the Flies’s GOCF (generalized observability canonical form) [15]. The dynamical SMC for non-linear systems have some advantages, which are the possibility of chattering-free control inputs [16] and good state response. Also, the outer acceleration control loop is designed by traditional PI controller design method. Furthermore, for application to real missile system, the estimation method of angle of attack by two different approaches is introduced. From a practical viewpoint, the proposed method is straightforward and can be implemented on real non-linear missile system. The performance and stability of proposed method are verified via computer simulation.

The article is organized as follows. The missile dynamics for application of non-linear control design method is first described and the asymptotic output tracking problem from the perspective of dynamical variable structure feedback control isrecalled. The design of the outer loop controller is analysed afterwards and two different estimator structures for the angle of attack are introduced. Simulation results are presented in order to illustrate the behaviour of the loop in terms of specification fulfilments and robustness to uncertainty.

sec.title: 2 PROBLEM DESCRIPTION
sec.p: Consider the tail-controlled pitch axis missile airframe. The control objective of the missile autopilot is to make the required acceleration track-given guidance command and must meet required performance criteria characterized by settling time, rising time, accuracy, and perturbation rejection.

sec.title: 2.1 Non-linear missile modelling
sec.p:
A non-linear model for the missile motion in the pitch plane is taken from the previous work [17] and the variables are defined in Fig. 1. Equations of motion in the pitch plane are given by (1) where α,q,Mm, and δ are angle of attack, pitch rate,Mach number, and control fin deflection angle, respectively, and m,V,Iyy,Q,S, and d are mass, velocity, pitching moment of inertia, dynamic pressure, reference area, and reference length, respectively. Fig. 1
Missile axes and dynamic variables
The aerodynamic coefficients in equation (1) are represented as the function of Mach number and angle of attack. (2) where bi and hi are the constant coefficients.
From equations (1) and (2), we get (3) where (4)

The aerodynamic coefficients are derived from wind tunnel measurements and associated with maximal admissible uncertainties Δmax, which is about 20–30 per cent. Hence, the uncertainties can be expressed as follows (5) The output of the system is the normal acceleration (6) where
Also, the actuator dynamics are described by a first-order differential equation (7) where ωa is the corner frequency and δc is the commanded fin deflection angle.

sec.title: 2.2 Performance specifications
sec.p:
The performance specifications are defined as follows.
The time to first peak: tr⩽0.35s.
Overshoot: %O.S ≤ 20%.
Tracking error ≤5%.
Actuator limit: speed (slew rate) ≤ 25°/s/g.
The model is valid for -10∘<α<10∘.

sec.title: 3 NON-LINEAR DYNAMIC CONTROLLER DESIGN
sec.p: Up to now, the asymptotic output tracking problem from the viewpoint of static or dynamic linearization is widely used for minimum phase system. The purpose of this section is to show that it is possible to make the missile acceleration tracks some guidance command and to meet the performance specifications through angle of attack form and incorporate concept of the dynamical SMC approach based on asymptotic output tracking control [13, 14]. Moreover, dynamical SMC design method is combined with output tracking control problem for improvement of robustness.

sec.title: 3.1 Dynamical SMC via asymptotic output tracking
sec.p: In this section, a dynamical discontinuous feedback strategy of sliding mode type is reviewed for asymptotic output tracking problems in non-linear dynamical system [13, 14].
Consider the non-linear SISO (single-input single-output) system (8) where x(t) is a n-dimensional state vector, y denotes the output, f(x,u) is the smooth vector, and h(x) is a smooth function.

Under the given analytic non-linear system equation (8), there exists a defined input-dependent state coordinate transformation that eliminates the state vector x(t) for equation (8) such that equation (8) may be written down in the input–output polynomial form (9) where m is a positive integer satisfying the rank condition (10) By setting zi=y(i-1), for i=1,…,m, equation (9) may be transformed into the canonical form (11) where k=(m-r) with r being the relative degree of the output function y with respect to the control input u, C is a non-linear function of the vector z=(z1,z2,…,zm)T, the control input u and a finite number of its time derivatives (u·1,…,u(k))T.

Let yR(t) be a reference output function differentiable at least n times with respect to the time t. Define the tracking error ɛ(t) as the difference between the actual system output y(t) and the reference output yR(t). (12) We then have (13)

By defining ɛi=ɛ(i-1)(i=1,…,m) as componentsof an error vector ɛ, equation (13) may be expressed as (14) where YR(t)=(yR(t),y·R(t),…,yR (m-1)(t))T and E=(ɛ1,ɛ2,…,ɛm), C is a non-linear function of the desired output.
The sliding surface is specified in terms of the output tracking error co-ordinates as (15) where the parameters βi are chosen such that the polynomial (16) be Hurwitz stable.
Equation (15) may be rewritten such that (17)
By reference [13], the following proposition is basic

sec.title: Proposition
sec.p:
Let μ and W represent strictly positive quantities and‘sgn’ stands for the signum function, which is defined as
Then, the scalar discontinuous system (19) globally exhibits a sliding regime on w = 0. Furthermore, any trajectory starting on the initial value w = w(0), at time t = 0, reaches the condition w = 0 in finite time T, given by (20)

Consider an auxiliary output variable w, defined in terms of the output tracking error coordinates ɛi(i=1,…,n) as (21) If we impose on the evolution of the auxiliary output variable w, the discontinuous dynamics considered in equation (19), one obtains, from equations (14) and (21) (22) Using equation (13), the dynamic controller can be computed from the following equation (23) The ideal sliding dynamics, obtained from equations (14) and (21) and the invariance conditions: w=0,dw/dt=0, is given by (24) which exhibits an asymptotically stable motion towards the origin of the error coordinates. Consequently, the output tracking error function ɛ1 converges asymptotically to zero. The asymptotically equilibrium point of the error signal is given by ɛ1=ɛ2=…=ɛm=0. For the exact tracking, the resulting dynamic control has the following expression (25)

sec.title: 4 OUTER LOOP CONTROLLER DESIGN
sec.p: In the previous section, the non-linear dynamic controller has been designed to track angle of attack references. However, the objective of this study is to track a reference acceleration. Hence, the angle of attack controller needs to be augmented by an outer loop in order to control the acceleration.

The design specifications require the robustness with respect to aerodynamic coefficient variations of about 30 percent. Hence, a cascaded control structure is introduced, as shown in Fig. 2. The outer loop is controlled by a PI controller such that the closed loop satisfies performance requirements. Fig. 2
Non-linear controller structure including outer loop
The parameters in the outer-loop controller may be selected based on a linearized analysis in which the closed-loop dynamics are approximately second order.
Define the controller structure as (46) and the transfer function from αc to α simplifies to (47) where τ is the time constant value.
Also, if we assume that the relation between α and Az can be represented as (48) If we consider the desired closed-loop characteristics as (49) then controller gains are determined as (50)

sec.title: 5 DESIGN OF ANGLE OF ATTACK ESTIMATOR
5.1 Estimation of angle of attack using non-linear observer
sec.p: In case of the missile system, the acceleration and rate are available through the measurement sensors. However, the angle of attack cannot be used directly. An observer is then necessary. Under some simplifying assumptions, an efficient quadratic observer may be obtained using simpler procedure [12]. It is possible to find a quadratic Lyapunov function for it. This non-linear observer is merely given by (51) where K is chosen so as to ensure (52) for some positive real number σ, which guarantees exponential stability for the observer (choose V(x)=x2as a Lyapunov function).

sec.title: 5.2 Estimation of angle of attack based on table (Aztoα)
sec.p:
In this section, very simple estimation method for practical implementation is introduced. This method uses the table which has the relation between acceleration and angle of attack. The proposed method can be very easily implemented using the table considering variation of acceleration with respect to angle of attack. Figure 3 shows the simple procedure for estimation of angle of attack. Fig. 3
Estimation of angle of attack using table Aztoα

sec.title: 6 SIMULATION STUDY
sec.p: To confirm the performance of the proposed non-linear control scheme, simulations were carried out. Parameter values used in this simulation are same as in reference [17].

sec.title: Missile structure data
sec.p: Mach number = 2.5
Mass = 80 kg, pitch moment of inertia: Iyy=66kgm2

sec.title: Aerodynamic data
sec.p: In this section, to confirm the performance of this control scheme applied to the pitch autopilot, simulations were carried out. The missile model used in simulation is a generic surface-to-air missile and is given as follows.

Note that this approximation is valid for −10°<α <10° and 1.8<Mm<2.6. Figure 4 shows the aerodynamic coefficients Cz and Cm versus missile Mach number and angle of attack for a generic short range surface-to-air missile model. Solid lines are for thewind tunnel test data and circle points present the calculated values using the above aerodynamic coefficients model. Fig. 4
Cz and Cm: (a) Cz and (b) Cm

sec.title: 6.1 Simulation result of angle of attack controller (without outer loop)
sec.p: This simulation is performed with no outer loop controller (α-controller). For the simulation, the control parameters are selected as follows

Figure 5 shows the response of angle of attack for the nominal case (without considering the uncertainty). It shows the good asymptotic tracking of the angle of attack, which is equivalent to a good asymptotic tracking of the desired acceleration. Figure 6 shows the responses including angle of attack estimator designed by two different methods. For the non-linear observer, we select the value of the K as −0.5. This result is shown that there is no difficulty in designing a non-linear quadratic observer, or, using Aztoα table. All responses of the nominal case with estimator have a very good performance with some demanded command. Fig. 5
Responses for the nominal case (without outer loop: α-control): (a) angle of attack, (b)acceleration, (c) control input, and (d) control speed Fig. 6
Responses with angle of attack estimator (without outer loop: α-control): (a) angle of attack, (b) acceleration, (c) control input, and (d) control speed

sec.title: 6.2 Simulation results of acceleration controller
sec.p: For the simulation, the control parameters are selected as follows

Figure 7 shows the response of variables related to the control when there is no uncertainty. The figures show almost identical step response with some demanded acceleration command. Small difference between the command and the response in Fig. 7 occurs as a result of using constant proportional gain and integral rate in equation (46). Fig. 7
Responses for the nominal case (acceleration control): (a) acceleration, (b) angle of attack, (c) control input, and (d) control speed

sec.title: Consideration of uncertainties in aerodynamic coefficients
sec.p: where Δ is -1<Δ<1.

Figures 8 and 9 show the results when ± 30 percent uncertainties exist in aerodynamic coefficients Cn and Cm. The results indicate good tracking performance even in the presence of large uncertainties. In Fig. 10, we may observe the characteristics of output acceleration with respect to the effects of Cn and Cm. In Figs 12 and 13, proposed autopilot also exhibits an uniform performance in terms of rise time and steady-state error despite the fact that a wide range of flight conditions (Mach 2.0–2.6) are traversed the same as in Fig. 11. All results show that all design specifications are satisfied and the performance of angle of attack estimator designed by two different methods indicates good tracking performance. Fig. 8
Response with + 30% uncertainties on aerodynamic coefficients (acceleration control): (a)acceleration, (b) angle of attack, (c) control input, and (d) control speed Fig. 9
Response with −30% uncertainties on aerodynamic coefficients (acceleration control): (a)acceleration, (b) angle of attack, (c) control input, and (d) control speed Fig. 10
Performance comparison with the variation of uncertainty on the Cz and Cm: (a)comparison of acceleration response (b) comparison of angle of attack response, (c) comparison of control input, and (d) comparison of control speed Fig. 11
Variation of Mach number Fig. 12
Responses for nominal case including the variation of velocity: (a) acceleration (b) control input Fig. 13
Responses for uncertain case including the variation of velocity: (a) acceleration and (b)control input

sec.title: 6.3 Stability study
sec.p:
As we mentioned, the control objective is to make the output track some reference acceleration and the whole system is stabilized. In this section, the relative stability through the computer simulation is confirmed. Figure 14 shows the result when 70 ms time delay exists in the inner (control input) and outer loops. Also, Fig. 15 presents the response for two times control input (2×δc) and error of outer loop (2×(Azc-Az)), respectively. From these simulation results, the stability margin of the whole system has at least more than gain margin 6 dB and phase margin 60°. Fig. 14
Simulation results with 70 ms time delay in control command and outer loop: (a) delay exists in inner loop and (b) delay exists in outer loop Fig. 15
Simulation results for 2×δc and 2×(Azc-Az): (a) inner loop, 2×δc and (b) outer loop, 2×(Azc-Az)

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this article, we have investigated non-linear controller for the stabilization and output tracking of the non-minimum phase missile. Herein, it is seen that despite the non-linear effects and aerodynamic uncertainties, employing cascade regulations are suitable for the application presented. The inner loop provides the desired linear response to the demanded angle of attack and the acceleration outer loop, including a classical PI controller, provides the desired response to the acceleration command. Computer simulations indicate that this approach is very promising to apply to the autopilot design for the missiles which are highly non-linear in aerodynamics. In addition, the high-precision tracking performance is achieved even in the presence of large uncertainties on the aerodynamic coefficients of the missile. Also, the angle of attack estimators designed by two different methods have good estimation performance. Through the computer simulation,the stability margin of global loop is verified. From the simulation results, we can conclude that our PI-non-linear dynamic control design method overcomes effectively the non-minimum phase characteristics and non-linearities of missile. Further studies will consist applying this control method to other missile systems in order to confirm its performance. Also, we will consider the non-linear effects between the normal acceleration and angle of attack to obtain the proper controller gains of outer loop in further studies.
